newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal says Eurostat would cut debt/GDP ratio.
newsitem.headline: Portugal says Eurostat would cut debt/GDP ratio.

text.p: The Finance Ministry said accounting procedures laid down by Eurostat, the European Union's statistics body, would result in a cut of around five percentage points in Portugal's debt-to-gross domestic product (GDP) ratio -- a key EMU criterion.
It said that under the new definition, the ratio would fall to 64.3 percent in 1997, from the government's forecast 69 percent.
The debt-to-GDP ratio is one of the criteria for entry to the European Union's economic and monetary union (EMU).
It said the figure for 1996 would have been 65.4 percent, down from some 70 percent that the government had calculated.
The reference value for entry to the single currency is set at 60 percent, although it can be above this if it is sufficiently diminishing in a downward trend.
The ministry said that the accounting changes would have no impact on Portugal's public sector deficit.
